Hi! Unfortunately we're not at the point yet where we can formalize a typical quantum information paper. To get an idea of where we are currently, we just recently got the continuous functional calculus in mathlib, which lets us apply functions to operators, and we're now formalizing things like real powers of positive operators (see e.g. docs#CFC.rpow, which landed in mathlib yesterday). We don't have CP maps yet; they should be within reach once #15277 lands.

Things like the LSD theorem are still pretty far away. Defining the von Neumann entropy, conditional entropy and mutual information and proving their basic properties requires things like the operator monotonicity of the log, which in turn relies on integral representations of real powers (which I'm currently working on), etc. We'll get there though!

Yes, what Frédéric said is definitely true, formalizing a full theorem is far away. I admit that things like the continuous functional calculus are well beyond my ken. And, I should clarify that when I say "writing down the LSD theorem", I in fact mean that merely _stating_ the theorem (where the relevant definitions are all filled in without sorrys) would be a milestone for me, not necessarily _proving_ it.

Just to set expectations, neither of our projects have any mention of "qubits", "gates", "circuits", "fermions", "bosons", "Gaussian states", and so on. The Mathlib attitude towards development is that generally such things would come _after_ defining things like Hilbert spaces and states and operations and so on.

Of course, for the more applied QI theorist, they might be content to just start outright with their own definitions of Gaussian states as (say) PSD matrices with certain attributes, without necessarily linking them to Hilbert spaces or CPTP maps. For instance, the Lean 3 repository that you linked, the No Cloning theorem the is stated in fairly 'direct' language: https://github.com/duckki/lean-quantum/blob/160cabcbd22bf24819b72930f56578e23b109a27/src/theorems/no-cloning.lean#L57 It can be read as a purely linear algebraic result, without needing to reference anything physical. Depending on your goals, this might be totally fine.

The downside is that if someone then wants a slightly different version of the theorem, it becomes a totally different statement. ("What if I want to allow non-unitary maps -- a general CPTP map?" / "What if I don't just care about qubits, and I want a different system?" / "What if I want the version where s could be a mixed state?" / "What I let the unitary use ancillas?" / "What if I actually want to prove that there exists an epsilon > 0 so that I can't clone with fidelity 1-epsilon, that is, not only is perfect cloning impossible, but even arbitrarily-close-to-perfect cloning is impossible?") These would require a substantial work to prove separately. If your no-cloning theorem is "linked" to the rest of quantum theory, then most of these would follow immediately from this special case of the no-cloning theorem, by combining it with other general facts of quantum theory. (Respectively: "Your CPTP map could get purified to a unitary." / "If it was true on some other system, it would be true on qubits too" / "The ancillas won't help, because that just gives another CPTP map." / "The set of CPTP operations is topologically closed, so arbitrarily-close-to-perfect cloning would imply perfect cloning.")
You might have already been aware of all that but I wanted to spell it out just to be clear :)

Actually, I just noticed now -- that no_cloning_1 is a fairly incorrect formalization, because there is no requirement that s is unit-norm. There is an even more trivial contradiction where you take s to be any vector of norm 2, and then since the unitary U preserves norm, it is of course not going to hold that U ⬝ (s ⊗ |0⟩) = s ⊗ s.

Maybe that's a slight lesson about the risks of just going with your own "simple" definitions... :)
There's another Lean4 repo around somewhere that is trying to do QIT, and that had a very similar problem with stating no cloning!

Alex Meiburg said:

Maybe that's a slight lesson about the risks of just going with your own "simple" definitions... :)

I think that's a lesson about the risks of going with a definition without building some API for it. It's very easy to have bugs in definitions, Lean won't catch them for you. But once you start proving lemmas about it, if the definition is wrong, chances are that you'll notice the problem sooner or later.

Things like the LSD theorem are still pretty far away. Defining the von Neumann entropy, conditional entropy and mutual information and proving their basic properties requires things like the operator monotonicity of the log, which in turn relies on integral representations of real powers (which I'm currently working on), etc. We'll get there though!
